question_desc:
On 31st December 2005 cash book of Subhash showed a debit bank balance of Rs. 75000. When compared with Pass book, the following facts were discovered :

2. on 28th December, three cehques of RS. 6000, Rs. 8000 and Rs. 12000 were issued, but these were not yet presented.

3. on 31st December, bank credited Rs. 1250 as interest but this was not recorded in the cash book.
4.Similarly, bank had charged Rs. 150 but this was not recoded in the cash book.
Required : Calculate balance as per bank pass book as on 31st December 2005.

5. Pass book showed bank charges of Rs. 20 debited by the bank.
6. One of the debtors deposited a sum of Rs. 500 in the bank account to the firm on 20th December, bit the intimation in this respect was received from the bank on 2nd January.

1. Balance as per pass book on 31st December, 2005 is Rs. 9250
2. Cheques of Rs. 5100 were issued during the month of December, but of these cheques of Rs. 1200 were presented in the month of January, 2006 and one cheque for Rs. 200 was not presented for payment.

4. A customer has deposited Rs. 800 into the bank directly.
5. The bank has credited the merchant for Rs. 200 as interest and has debited him for Rs. 30 as bank charges, for which there are no corresponding entries in cash book.

1. The cheques and drafts sent to the bank but not collected and credited, amounted to Rs. 790 and there cheques drawn for Rs. 300, Rs. 150 and Rs. 200 respectively were not presented for payment till 31st January next year.
2. Bank has debited insurance premium amounting to Rs. 1000 but it has not been entered in the cash book and locker rent or Rs. 500
3. The bank has charged Rs. 13 as its commission for collecting outstation cheques and has allowed interest Rs. 10 on the traders balance.
Required : calculate balance as per bank pass book and show the balance as shown by the cash book :

The following cheques were paid into bank in Decemebr, but were credited in January
1. Seema Rs. 3500, Sangita Rs. 2500, Sonia Rs. 2000
2. The following cheques were issued by the firm in Dec. but were presented in January : Arti Rs. 4000, Sharati Rs. 4500

4. The pass book shows a debit entry of Rs. 1000 for bank charges and credit entry of Rs.2000 for interest.
5. Interest on investment Rs. 2500 collected by bank appeared in the pass book
6. The bank balance as per pass book was Rs. 59270 on 31st December, 2005.

Mr. Shakti, who had just been grated an overdraft facility of Rs. 80000 by his bankers, reports a bank balance as per his pass book of Rs. 10000 (credit), as on 30.9.2005.
Scrutiny shows the following differences between the two records and you are asked to calculate balance as per bank pass book.
1. Two cheques of Rs. 3000 each were deposited with and cleared by the bankers in September itself, but in the cash book an entry for each was made on the credit side.
2. The bank had credited Rs. 1500 for interest and debited Rs. 25 for bank charges. The former was recorded in the Cash Book for Rs. 1000 only, while the latter for Rs. 52.
3. Cheques totaling Rs. 15000 were issued to creditors, but the bank had paid out cheques worth Rs. 6000 only.
4. The pass book alone showed a direct deposit of Rs. 4000 by a customer, Mr. Locke, and a club subscription of Rs. 400 paid by the bankers as per standing instructions.

Mr. R. Sinha reports a bank balance of Rs. 10500 (credit), from his cash book as on 30.6.2001. As the bank statement received for the month reflects another figure, a reconciliation is needed. The following data is available :
1. Cheques deposited in the month totaled Rs. 90000. Of these, one cheque for Rs. 3600 was debited in the cash column (cash book) and another cheque for Rs. 900 only was accounted as Rs. 9000 by Sinhas clerk.
2. A transfer of Rs. 30000 from owners personal savings account to the current account was only accounted for by the bankers.
3. Two cheques of Rs. 10000 each issued every month to the regular supplier, were accounted for, but one cheque was misplaced but the supplier in his office its encashment was therefore, pending.
4. A bank draft for Rs. 500 issued, favouring M. O was debited in the Cash book and till 30.6.2001 it had not been encashed by Mr. O. the cost of the draft Rs. 10 was entered twice in the cash book.
Required : calculate balance as per bank pass book as on 30.6.2001 :

question_desc: When Balance Sheet prepared after the new partnership agreement, Assets and liabilities are recorded at:

A and B are partners sharing the profit in the ratio of 3:2. They take C as the new partner, who brings in Rs. 25,000 against capital and Rs. 10,000 against goodwill. New profit sharing ratio is 1:1:1. C is able to bring only his share of Capital. How this will be treated in the books of the firm.

option_b: Goodwill will be raised to Rs. 30,000 in old profit sharing ratio

New profit sharing ratio is 1:1:1. C bought cash for his share of Capital and agreed to compensate to A and B outside the firm. How this will be treated in the books of the firm.
option_a: Cash bought in by C will only be credited to his capital account.
option_b: Goodwill will be raised to full value in old ratio
option_c: Goodwill will be raised to full value in new ratio
option_d: Cash bought by C will be credited to his account and debited with his share of goodwill, which will be debited to A and Bs account in sacrificing ratio.a

Goodwill at Rs. 30,000 (book value nil)

X, Y, Z are equal partners in a firm. Z retires from the firm. The new profit sharing ratio between X and Y is 1:2. Find the gaining ratio.

If a partner dies, then JLP will be reckoned at ------------

XYZ are three partners in a firm. They are sharing profit and loss in the ratio of 2:2:1. Y retires from the firm on 31st March 06. The firm decided not to raise goodwill A/c in the books of A/c. What entry will be made for treatment of goodwill at the time of retirement of Y
option_a: Debit X and Z, credit Y (for share of Y in the gaining ratio)
option_b: Goodwill A/c Dr, Credit Ys Capital A/c
option_c: Goodwill A/c Dr. Credit XYZ Capital A/c
option_d: Goodwill A/c Dr. Credit XZ A/c

question_desc: A, B and C are partners sharing profits and losses in the ratio of 3:2:1. C retires on a decided date and goodwill of the firm is to be valued at Rs. 120,000. The amount payable to retiring partner on account of goodwill will be:

A, B and C were partners sharing profits and losses in the ratio of 3:2:1. A retired and Goodwill of the firm is to be valued at Rs. 48,000 and Goodwill Account is to be raise which is not appearing in the balance sheet. What will be the treatment for goodwill?
option_a: Credited to Revaluation Account at Rs. 48,000
option_b: Credited to Partners capital account Rs. 48,000 in profits sharing ratio
option_c: Only As capital account credited with Rs. 24,000
option_d: Only As capital account credited with Rs. 48,000

question_desc: A, B and C were partners sharing profits and losses in the ration of 4:3:2 respectively. B retired on 31st March, 2006 on which date the capitals of A, B and C after all necessary adjustments stood at Rs. 39300, Rs. 39600 & Rs. 18300 respectively. The entire capital of the firm as newly constituted is fixed at Rs. 56000 between A and C in the proportion of five eighths and three-eighths after passing entries in their accounts for adjustments. Calculate the actual cash to be paid off or to be brought in by the continuing partners.
option_a: A and C will each withdraw Rs. 800
option_b: A will withdraw Rs. 4300, C will bring in Rs. 2700
option_c: A will bring in Rs. 4300, C will withdraw Rs. 2700
option_d: A will withdraw Rs. 2700, C will bring in Rs. 4300

question_desc: A, B and C were partners sharing profits and losses in the ration of 4:3:2 respectively. B retired on 31st March, 2006 on which date the capitals of A, B and C after all necessary adjustments stood at Rs. 131600, Rs. 114450 and Rs. 67600 respectively. The entire capital of the reconstituted firm will be re-adjusted by bringing in or paying off cash so that the future capital of A & C be in their future profit sharing ratio. Calculate the amount of cash to be paid off or to be brought in by the continuing partners.
option_a: A and C will each withdraw Rs. 1200
option_b: A and C will each bring in Rs. 1200
option_c: A will bring in R.s 1200, C will withdraw Rs. 1200
option_d: A will withdraw Rs. 1200, C will bring in Rs. 1200

question_desc: A, B and C were partners sharing profits and losses in the ratio of 5:3:2 respectively. B retired on 31st March, 2006 on which date the capitals of A, B and C after all necessary adjustments stood at Rs. 86400, Rs. 73200 and Rs. 22400 respectively. The cash and bank balance on 31st March, 2006 amounted to Rs. 8000. B was to be paid through cash brought in by A and C in such a way as to make their capitals proportionate to their new profit sharing ratio which was to be A-3/5th and C-2/5th. Calculate the amount of Cash to be paid off or to be brought in by the continuing partners assuming that a minimum cash and bank balance of Rs. 6000 was to be maintained.
option_a: A will bring in Rs. 49600 and C will bring in Rs. 21600
option_b: A will bring in Rs. 21600 and C will bring in Rs. 49600
option_c: A will withdraw Rs. 21600 and C will bring in Rs. 49600
option_d: A will bring in Rs. 21600 and C will withdraw Rs. 49600

question_desc: Increase in liability at the time of retirement of partner is................
Decrease in liability at the time of retirement of partner is..................
Increase in assets at the time of retirement of partner is               ........................

A partner may retire................
option_a: With the consent of all the partners
option_b: In accordance with an express agreement by the partners
option_c: Where the partnership is at will, by giving notice in writing to all the other partners of his intention to retire

When the Joint Life Insurance Policy premium is treated as expenses, the amount received on death of the partner is transferred to

ABC are three partners in a partnership firm. They took a joint life policy of Rs. 21,000 at an annual premium of Rs. 1000 per annum. C dies on 15th April 06. On the date of death of B Joint life policy appeared in the books of firm at Rs. 3000. The policy amount of Rs. 21,000 was received at the time of death of C. What amount will be transferred to the partners capital account for treatment of JLP.
option_a: Dr JLP Rs. 18,000, Credit A, B and Cs Capital A/c @ Rs. 6000
option_b: Dr JLP Rs. 21,000, Credit A, B and Cs Capital A/c @ Rs. 7000
option_c: Dr JLP Rs. 3,000, Credit A, B and Cs Capital A/c @ Rs. 1000
option_d: Dr. JLP Rs. 6000, Credit A, B and Cs Capital A/c @ Rs. 2,000

question_desc: PQR are three partners in a partnership firm. They took a Joint life policy of Rs. 30,000 at an annual premium of Rs. 1000 per annum. R dies on 10th April 07. Joint Life policy of Rs. 10,00,000. Fixed assets of Rs. 12,00,000. On 1st June C died and on same date assets were revalued. The executors of C will get along with capital:
option_c: Proportionate share of profit upto the date of death

question_desc: Joint Life Policy amount received by a firm is distributed in ---------
option_c: Old profit sharing ratio of partners

question_desc: As per Section 37 of the Indian Partnership Act 1932, the executors would be entitled at their choice to the interest calculated from the date of death till the date of payment on the final amount due to the dead partner at .. Percentage per annum.

option_d: Whole of Rs. 1,20,000 will be paid to A
